filedesc.updatestmt:
Blake’s experiences in the London social circle of the Rev. A. S. Mathew and his wife Harriet in the 1780s gave him both inspiration and opportunities. An Island in the Moon, a manuscript fragment that includes poems and songs in wacky satirical contexts, is an early vehicle for his impressions of the Mathew circle. Poetical Sketches is a more serious, in some respects major, literary experiment that grew out of the accumulated earlier efforts of this multi-talented engraver’s apprentice to write poems and poetic prose sketches some of which he later probably recited and sang in company. The Mathews must have been impressed, because they joined with the artist and sculptor John Flaxman to subsidize the printing, in 1783, of Blake's first and only typographical collection of poetry. (For what is known about the printing, see the note under Publisher on the Copy Information page.) It was a rudimentary printing job rather than a formally published volume: perhaps fifty copies of eleven sheets that could be folded and assembled into small volumes with a title page presenting "W. B." as author followed by a one page, unsigned "Advertisement" for these displays of "poetic originality, which merited some respite from oblivion" (Object 2). The uncorrected sheets were apparently left in Blake’s hands to do with as he saw fit, which, surprisingly, was nothing more than to present individual volumes to friends and patrons now and then throughout his life. He (and others) variously corrected and emended some copies but left others untouched. Only about half—at the latest count twenty-four—survive.
Despite its somewhat unpromising origins, Poetical Sketches remains vitally important in its revelations of Blake’s reading habits and early accomplishments—several fine poems, including the often anthologized "I Lov'd the Jocund Dance" and "How Sweet I Roam'd from Field to Field"—along with strong anticipations of his developing styles and interests. The collection materializes at a productive literary intersection of Elizabethan and neoclassical poetics, biblical allusion, late eighteenth-century innovations, emergent romantic modes, and idiosyncratic mythopoeic genius. A Shakespearean invocation to the muse begins "King Edward the Third," while it, along with "Edward IV" and "King John," sets a tone similar to Shakespeare's history plays. The stimulus of popular eighteenth century poems—James Thomson's The Seasons (finished in 1730), Edward Young's Night Thoughts, and James Macpherson's pseudo-medieval Ossian poems—can be felt. And, of course, Blake’s key predecessor John Milton leaves his mark, particularly in "Contemplation" and "Samson."
Although the earliest works may have been drafted when Blake was an "untutored youth" (Advertisement Object 2), the collection conveys a powerful sense of the original author he was fast becoming. His visionary or prophetic mode ("Gwin, King of Norway"), his underlying social and political commitments (in the ironic "King Edward the Third"), and his easy assimilation of new literary trends (the gothic "Fair Elinor") are all evident. As miscellaneous as it is, Poetical Sketches anticipates the major literary work soon to come.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

imprint.publisher: John Nichols(?) The work was printed but never formally published. According to John Thomas Smith, the print run was funded by John Flaxman and the Rev. Anthony Stephen Mathew, the latter having been persuaded by his wife to join Flaxman in the endeavor (*Nollekens and His Times*, 1828, quoted in Bentley, *Records* page 605). Smith also claims Rev. Mathew may have then written the advertisement (page 605). Noting the potential unreliability of Smith's account, Bentley surmises that Flaxman's aunt and uncle, Jane and John Matthews (unrelated to Rev. Mathew but printsellers and publishers themselves), may have contributed to or consulted on the printing of *Poetical Sketches* ("John Flaxman and the Mathew Clan," *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* 67 [1963]: 443-54). Michael Phillips, who also questions Smith's accuracy, proposes that the printer was John Nichols based on typographic similarities between *Poetical Sketches* and other works printed by Nichols, as well as mutual friends connecting Flaxman to Nichols ("William Blake and the 'Unincreasable Club': The Printing of *Poetical Sketches*," *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* 80 [1976]: 6-18). Furthermore, Phillips mentions that Blake could have been acquainted with Nichols through his apprenticeship to Basire, but that Flaxman's association with three of Nichols' friends ( each of whom received a copy of *Poetical Sketches*) perhaps allowed Flaxman to arrange the printing of *Sketches* with Nichols (pages 13-17).

objdescid.note: According to the advertisem ent, Blake composed *Poetical Sketches* between the ages of twelve and twenty.

objinfo.printdate: 1783 Including the previously unrecorded Copy Y, auctioned in 2011, there are twenty-four extant copies of *Poetical Sketches*. Twelve copies contain corrections by Blake and others (Essick, "Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 45.4 [spring 2012], pages 108-109; Bentley page 346).
objinfo.numberleaves: 38There are 38 leaves and 76 pages total. Blank pages are not reproduced here.
objinfo.medium: Type with handwritten corrections and additions in pen and ink.
objinfo.watermark: none Laid paper with chain lines 2.8 cm. apart. Bentley notes that the paper is defective and possibly from an odd lot (*Writings* volume 2, page 1685).
objinfo.pennednumbers: 2-70Page numbers are at the outside corners of pages with running heads or, in the case of pages where the first line on a page is the title line, in the middle of the top margin in square brackets, except for pages 15 and 16, which are in round brackets.
objinfo.binding: Originally bound in light blue cloth boards with a red leather label on the spine. Rebound for Robert Hoe in Citron levant morocco, inside front cover is stamped with "THE CLUB BINDERY 1908". Page edges, frames on the covers, and title on the spine ("BLAKE/ - / POETICAL SKETCHES/ LOND./ 1783.") are gilt.

provenance.name: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Given by Blake to Charles Tulk c. 1810; sold by Edward Duperner, Sotheby's, 20 June 1906, lot 937, £109 to B. F. Stevens; acquired by Robert Hoe, who rebound it in 1908; auctioned from Hoe's estate by Anderson Auction Company, 25 April 1911, lot 389, to George D. Smith for $725 for Henry Huntington; now in the Huntington Library.

repository.institution: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens

objnote.p: In the first two objects, two-page spreads are given to provide a sense of materiality of the printed book. Remaining objects revert to the Archive's standard of single-page cropped images.

l.note: At the top of the page, in lines 1-2, "To Charles Tulk..." is inscribed in pen and ink by Blake. Bentley states that Tulk likely received this copy after 1810 (*Writings* volume 2, page 1686).

lg.l: POETICAL
SKETCHES.

By
W. B. William Blake
LONDON:
Printed in the Year M DCC LXXXIII1783.

objnote.p: In the first two objects, two-page spreads are given to provide a sense of materiality of the printed book. Remaining objects revert to the Archive's standard of single-page cropped images.
Bentley notes that, according to J. T. Smith, Rev. Mathew wrote the advertisement (*Nollekens and His Times*, 1828, qtd. in Bentley, *Records* page 605).

lg.l: ADVERTISEMENT.

THE following Sketches were the
pro- production
ductionproduction of untutored youth, commenced
in his twelfth, and occasionally resumed by
the author till his twentieth year; since
which time, his talents having been wholly
directed to the attainment of excellence in
his profession, he has been deprived of the
leisure requisite to such a revisal of these sheets,
as might have rendered them less unfit to
meet the public eye.
Conscious of the irregularities and defects
to be found in almost every page, his friends
have still believed that they possessed a poe- poetical
ticalpoetical originality, which merited some respite
from oblivion. These their opinions remain,
however, to be now reproved or confirmed by
a less partial public.

l.note: In the printed text, this line is a triple rule.

lg.l: MISCELLANEOUS POEMS.
TO SPRING.
O THOU, with dewy locks, who lookest
down
Thro' Through the clear windows of the morning; turn
Thine angel eyes upon our western isle,
Which in full choir hails thy approach, O Spring!
The hills tell each other, and the list'ning listening
Vallies Valleys hear; all our longing eyes are turned
Up to thy bright pavillionspavilions: issue forth,
And let thy holy feet visit our clime.
Come o'er over the eastern hills, and let our winds
Kiss thy perfumed garments; let us taste
Thy morn and evening breath; scatter thy pearls

Upon our
love-sick lovesick land that mourns for thee.

objnote.p:
While most of the emendations across the corrected copies are assumed to have been made by Blake, the authorship of some emendations is disputed. Unless otherwise noted, our default attribution is to Blake. For further information on the emendations in *Poetical Sketches* and their attributions, see:
Bentley pages 343-54
Bentley, *Writings* vol 2, pages 749-99
[Essick, Robert. "Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 (spring 2012)](http://bq.blakearchive.org/45.4.essick#PS)
Essick, *Huntington* pages 176-78
Erdman pages 408-45, 846-48
[Phillips, Michael. "Blake’s Corrections in *Poetical Sketches*," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 4.2 (fall 1970)](http://bq.blakearchive.org/4.2.phillips).

lg.l: O deck her forth with thy fair fingers; pour

Thy soft kisses on her bosom; and putMichael Phillips notes "soft" seems to be deleted by pen in Copy T, but that this apparant deletion could be a discolored perforation ("Blake's Corrections in *Poetical Sketches*", *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 4.2 [fall 1970], page 45).
Thy golden crown upon her languish'd languished head,
Whose modest tresses were bound up for thee!

OTHOU, who passest passes
thro' through our vallies valleys in
Thy strength, curb thy fierce steeds, allay
the heat
That flames from their large nostrils! thou, O
Summer,
Oft Often pitched'st pitched here thy golden tent, and oft
Beneath our oaks hast slept, while we beheld
With joy, thy ruddy limbs and flourishing hair.Bentley notes that in Copy W, "flourishing" is emended to "flowing" by "an unBlakelike hand" (*Writings* volume 2, page 750n).
Beneath our thickest shades we oft often have heard
Thy voice, when noon upon his fervid car
Rode o'er over the deep of heaven; beside our springs
Sit down, and in our mossy valliesvalleys, on
Some bank beside a river clear, throw thy
Silk draperies off, and rush into the stream:
Our vallies valleys love the Summer in his pride.
Our bards are fam'd famed who strike the silver wire:
Our youth are bolder than the southern swains:
Our maidens fairer in the sprightly dance:
We lack not songs, nor instruments of joy,
Nor echoes sweet, nor waters clear as heaven,
Nor laurel wreaths against the sultry heat.
TO AUTUMN.
OAUTUMN, laden with fruit, and stained
With the blood of the grape, pass not, but sit
Beneath my shady roof, there thou may'st mayest may rest,
And tune thy jolly voice to my fresh pipe;
And all the daughters of the year shall dance!
Sing now the lusty song of fruits and flowers.
"The narrow bud opens her beauties to
"The sun, and love runs in her thrilling veins;
"Blossoms hang roundaround the brows of morning, and
"Flourish down the bright cheek of modest eve,
"Till clust'ring clustering Summer breaks forth into singing,
"And feather'd feathered clouds strew flowers round her
"head.
"The spirits of the air live on the smells
"Of fruit; and joy, with pinions light, roves round
"The gardens, or sits singing in the trees."
Thus sang the jolly Autumn as he sat,
Then rose, girded himself, and o'er over the bleak
Hills fled from our sight; but left his golden load.

lg.l: TO WINTER.
OWINTER! bar thine adamantine doors:
The north is thine; there hast thou built thy
dark
Deep-founded habitation. Shake not thy roofs,
Nor bend thy pillars with thine iron car.
He hears me not, but o'er over the yawning deep
Rides heavy; his storms are unchain'dunchained; sheathed
In ribbed steel, I dare not lift mine eyes;
For he hath rear'd reared his sceptre o'er over the world.
Lo! now the direful monster, whose skin clings
To his strong bones, strides o'er over the groaning rocks:

He withers all in silence, and in his handBentley notes that "in" is deleted from "in his hand" in this copy, as well as Copies B, E, F, O, Q, S, T, V, and W (*Writings* volume 2, page 752n). Erdman notes this correction occurs in eight copies (847). Essick records that in Copies C and S, the deletion is made by striking through "in" with pen and ink (*Huntington* pages 177-78). Essick also documents this change in Copy Y ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
Unclothes the earth, and freezes up frail life.
He takes his seat upon the cliffs, the mariner
Cries in vain. Poor little wretch! that deal'st deals
With storms; till heaven smiles, and the monster
Is driv'n driven yelling to his caves beneath mount Hecla.

lg.l: TO THE
EVENING STAR.
THOU fair-hair'd fair-haired angel of the evening,

Now, whilst while the sun rests on the mountains,Erdman reads "while" for "whilst" (410). Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 752n) and Erdman (847) note that in Copy Q, "whilst" is emended to "while".
light
Thy bright torch of love; thy radiant crown
Put on, and smile upon our evening bed!
Smile on our loves; and, while thou drawest draw the
Blue curtains of the sky, scatter thy silver dew
On every flower that shuts its sweet eyes
In timely sleep. Let thy west wind sleep on
The lake; speak silence with thy glimmering eyes,
And wash the dusk with silver. Soon, full soon,
Dost thou withdraw; then the wolf rages wide,
And the lion glares thro' through the dun forest:
The fleeces of our flocks are cover'd covered with
Thy sacred dew: protect them with thine in- influence
fluenceinfuence.
TO MORNING.
O HOLY virgin! clad in purest white,
Unlock heav'n's heaven's golden gates, and issue forth;
Awake the dawn that sleeps in heaven; let light
Rise from the chambers of the east, and bring

The honied honeyed
dew that
cometh comes on waking day.
O radiant morning, salute the sun,
Rouz'd Roused like a huntsman to the chacechase; and, with
Thy buskin'd buskined feet, appear upon our hills.

lg.l: FAIR ELENOR.
THE bell struck one, and shook the silent
tower;

The graves give up their dead: fair ElenorBentley notes that in Copy F, a contemporary hand has written a marginal comment in ink indicating "give" should be changed to "gave" (*Writings* volume 2, page 753n).
Walk'd Walked by the castle gate, and looked in.
A hollow groan ran thro' through the dreary vaults.
She shriek'd shrieked aloud, and sunk upon the steps

On the cold stone her pale cheeks. Sickly smellsBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 753) and Erdman (411) read "cheek" for "cheeks". Bentley notes that the "s" in "cheeks" is deleted in this copy as well as E, Q, S, and V (*Writings* volume 2, page 753n). Erdman notes this correction was made in four copies (847). Essick indicates that the "s" in this copy is struck through with pen and ink, and in Copy S it is rubbed out (*Huntington* pages 177-78). Essick also notes that the "s" is rubbed out in Copy Y ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
Of death, issue as from a sepulchresepulcher,
And all is silent but the sighing vaults.
Chill death withdraws his hand, and she revives;
Amaz'dAmazed, she finds herself upon her feet,
And, like a ghost, thro' through narrow passages
Walking, feeling the cold walls with her hands.
Fancy returns, and now she thinks of bones,
And grinning skulls, and corruptible death,
Wrap'd Wrapped in his shroud; and now, fancies she hears
Deep sighs, and sees pale sickly ghosts gliding.
At length, no fancy, but reality
Distracts her. A rushing sound, and the feet
Of one that fled, approaches—EllenElenor stood,
Like a dumb statue, froze to stone with fear.
The wretch approaches, crying, "The deed is
"done;
"Take this, and send it by whom thou wiltwill send;
"It is my life—send it to Elenor:—
"He's dead, and howling after me for blood!
"Take this," he cry'dcried; and thrust into her arms
A wet napkin, wrap'd wrapped about; then rush'd rushed
Past, howling: she receiv'd received into her arms
Pale death, and follow'd followed on the wings of fear.
They pass'd passed swift thro' through the outer gate; the wretch,

Howling, leap'd leaped leapt
o'er over the wall into the moat,

Stifling in mud. Fair
Ellen Elenor
pass'd passed the bridge,
And heard a gloomy voice cry, "Is it done?"
As the deer dear wounded Ellen Elenor flew over
The pathless plain; as the arrows that fly
By night; destruction flies, and strikes in darkness,
She fled from fear, till at her house arriv'darrived.
Her maids await her; on her bed she falls,
That bed of joy, where erst her lord hath press'dpressed:
"Ah, woman's fear!" she cry'dcried; "Ah, cursed
"duke!
"Ah, my dear lord! ah, wretched Elenor!
"My lord was like a flower upon the brows
"Of lusty May! Ah, life as frail as flower!

lg.l: "O ghastly death! withdraw thy cruel hand,
"Seek'st Seekest thou that flow'r flower to deck thy horrid
"temples?
"My lord was like a star, in highest heav'n heaven
"Drawn down to earth by spells and wickedness;
"My lord was like the opening eyes of day,
"When western winds creep softly o'er over the flowers:
"But he is darken'ddarkened; like the summer's noon,
"The breath of heaven dwelt among his leaves.
"O Elenor, weak woman, fill'd filled with woe!"
Thus having spoke, she raised up her head,
And saw the bloody napkin by her side,
Which in her arms she brought; and now, tenfold
More terrified, saw it unfold itself.

Her eyes were fix'dfixed; the bloody cloth unfolds,Essick notes that in Copy Y "a short horizontal line crossing the upper vertical of the 'h' of 'the' in 'the bloody cloth unfolds.'" This line could be unintentional ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
Disclosing to her sight the murder'd murdered head
Of her dear lord, all ghastly pale, clotted
With gory blood; it groan'dgroaned, and thus is spake:

"O Elenor, I am thy husband's head,A small patch of the paper is worn or scraped away, rendering the "y" in "thy" unclear. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 755) and Erdman (412) read "behold thy husband's head" for "I am thy husband's head". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 755n) notes that in Copies B, D, E, F, O, Q, S, and W, "I am" is deleted and replaced with "behold" in pen and ink. Erdman states that this revision was made in six copies (847). Essick notes this change also occurs in Copy Y, and specifies that "I am" is scraped off and replaced with "behold" in Copies S and Y (*Huntington* page 178) ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
"Who, sleeping on the stones of yonder tower,
"Was 'reft bereft of life by the accursed duke!
"A hired villain turn'd turned my sleep to death!
"O Elenor, beware the cursed duke,
"O give not him thy hand, now I am dead;
"He seeks thy love; who, coward, in the night,
"Hired a villain to bereave my life."
She sat with dead cold limbs, stiffen'd stiffened to stone;
She took the gory head up in her arms;
She kiss'd kissed the pale lips; she had no tears to shed;
She hugg'd hugged it to her breast, and groan'd groaned her last.
HOW sweet I roam'd roamed from field to field,
And tasted all the summer's pride,
'Till I the prince of love beheld,
Who in the sunny beams did glide!
He shew'd showed me lilies for my hair,
And blushing roses for my brow;
He led me through his gardens fair,
Where all his golden pleasures grow.
With sweet May dews my wings were wet,
And Phoebus fir'd fired my vocal rage;
He caught me in his silken net,
And shut me in his golden cage.
He loves to sit and hear me sing,
Then, laughing, sports and plays with me;
Then stretches out my golden wing,
And mocks my loss of liberty.
SONG.
MY silks and fine array,
My smiles and languish'd languished air,
By love are driv'n driven away;
And mournful lean Despair
Brings me yew to deck my grave:
Such end true lovers have.
His face is fair as heav'nheaven,
When springing buds unfold;

O why to him was't was it
giv'ngiven,
Whose heart is wintry cold?

His breast is love's all-worship'd all-worshipped tomb,The apparent hyphen may be an ink smudge or defect in the paper. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 757) and Erdman (413) both read "all worship'd".
Where all love's pilgrims come.
Bring me an axe and spade,
Bring me a winding sheet;
When I my grave have made,
Let winds and tempests beat:
Then down I'll lie, as cold as clay.
True love doth pass away!

lg.l: SONG.
LOVE and harmony combine,
And around our souls intwine,
While thy branches mix with mine,
And our roots together join.
Joys upon our branches sit,
Chirping loud, and singing sweet;
Like gentle streams beneath our feet
Innocence and virtue meet.
Thou the golden fruit dost bear,
I am clad in flowers fair;
Thy sweet boughs perfume the air,
And the turtle buildeth there.
There she sits and feeds her young,
Sweet I hear her mournful song;
And thy lovely leaves among,

There is love: I hear h er is tongue.Erdman reads "his" for "her" (414). Bentley notes that in this copy as well as Q and V, "her" is changed to "his" (*Writings* volume 2, page 757n). Erdman notes this change occurs in two copies (847), and Essick (*Huntington* page 177) specifies that in Copy C, the alteration is made by writing over the printed letters in pen and ink.
There his charming nest doth lay,
There he sleeps the night away;
There he sports along the day,
And doth among our branches play.

lg.l: SONG.
ILOVE the jocund dance,
The softly-breathing song,
Where innocent eyes do glance,
And where lisps the maiden's tongue.The punctuation at the end of this line is smeared. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 758) and Erdman (414) transcribe a period.
I love the laughing vale,
I love the echoing hill,
Where mirth does never fail,
And the jolly swain laughs his fill.Bentley notes that in Copy F, a contemporary hand has changed "his fill" to "still" in pen and ink (*Writings* volume 2, page 758n).
I love the pleasant cot,
I love the innocent bow'rbower,
Where white and brown is our lot,
Or fruit in the mid-day midday hour.
I love the oaken seat,
Beneath the oaken tree,
Where all the old villagers meet,
And laugh our sports to see.
I love our neighbours neighbors all,
But, Kitty, I better love thee;
And love them I ever shall;
But thou art all to me.
SONG.
MEMORY, hither come,
And tune your merry notes;
And, while upon the wind,
Your music floats,
I'll pore upon the stream,
Where sighing lovers dream,
And fish for fancies as they pass
Within the watery glass.
I'll drink of the clear stream,
And hear the linnet's song;
And there I'll lie and dream
The day along:
And, when night comes, I'll go
To places fit for woe;
Walking along the darken'd darkened valley,
With silent Melancholy.

lg.l: MAD SONG.
THE wild winds weep,
And the night is a-cold;
Come hither, Sleep,

And my griefs unfold: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 759) and Erdman (415) read "infold" for "unfold". Bentley notes that in Copies B, E, F, O, Q, S, and W, "unfold" is changed to "infold" (*Writings* volume 2, page 759n). Erdman notes this change occurs in six copies (847). Essick specifies that in Copy S, the left vertical of the "u" from "unfold" is scraped off and the right vertical is dotted as an "i" (*Huntington* page 178). Essick documents the same change is made in Copy Y ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
But lo! the morning peeps
Over the eastern steeps,

And the rustling beds of dawnBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 759) and Erdman (415) read "birds" for "beds". Bentley notes that in Copies B, C, D, E, F, O, Q, S, T, V, and W, "beds" has been deleted and replaced with "birds" (*Writings* volume 2, page 759n). Erdman notes that this correction occurs in seven copies (847). Essick indicates that in this copy, "beds" has been struck through with horizontal lines and "birds" has been written in pen and ink above the line (*Huntington* page 177). Essick documents the same change for Copy Y ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).
The earth do scorn.
Lo! to the vault
Of paved heaven,
With sorrow fraught
My notes are driven:
They strike the ear of night,
Make weep the eyes of day;
They make mad the roaring winds,
And with tempests play.
Like a fiend in a cloud
With howling woe,
After night I do croudcrowd,
And with night will go;
I turn my back to the east,
From whence comforts have increas'dincreased;
For light doth seize my brain

With frantic pain. Essick notes that in Copy Y, Blake has added a short line between the "a" and "i" in "pain." The meaning of this is unclear and may have been accidental ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.5 [spring 2012], page 119).
SONG.
FRESH from the dewy hill, the merry year
Smiles on my head, and mounts his flaming
car;
Round my young brows the laurel wreathes a shade,
And rising glories beam around my head.
My feet are wing'dwinged, while o'er over the dewy lawn,
I meet my maiden, risen like the morn:
Oh bless those holy feet, like angels' feet;
Oh bless those limbs, beaming with heav'nly heavenly light!
Like as an angel glitt'ring glittering in the sky,
In times of innocence, and holy joy;
The joyful shepherd stops his grateful song,
To hear the music of an angel's tongue.
So when she speaks, the voice of Heaven I hear: Erdman omits the colon after "hear" (416).
So when we walk, nothing impure comes near;
Each field seems Eden, and each calm retreat;
Each village seems the haunt of holy feet.
But that sweet village where my black-ey'd black-eyed maid,
Closes her eyes in sleep beneath night's shade:
Whene'er Whenever I enter, more than mortal fire
Burns in my soul, and does my song inspire.

lg.l: SONG.
WHEN early morn walks forth in sober
grey;
Then to my black ey'd eyed maid I haste away,
When evening sits beneath her dusky bow'rbower,
And gently sighs away the silent hour;
The village bell alarms, away I go;
And the vale darkens at my pensive woe.
To that sweet village, where my black ey'd eyed maid
Doth drop a tear beneath the silent shade,
I turn my eyes; and, pensive as I go,
Curse my black stars, and bless my pleasing woe.Bentley notes that in the margin of Copy F, "black" is changed to "ill" with pen and ink by a contemporary hand (*Writings* volume 2, page 761n).
OftOften when the summer sleeps among the trees,
Whisp'ring Whispering faint murmurs to the scanty breeze,
I walk the village round; if at her side
A youth doth walk in stolen joy and pride,
I curse my stars in bitter grief and woe,
That made my love so high, and me so low.
O should she e'er ever prove false, his limbs I'd tear,
And throw all pity on the burning air;
I'd curse bright fortune for my mixed lot,
And then I'd die in peace, and be forgot.
TO THE MUSES.
WHETHER on Ida's shady brow,
Or in the chambers of the East,
The chambers of the sun, that now
From antient ancient melody have ceas'dceased;
Whether in Heav'n Heaven ye wander fair,

Or the greeen green corners of the earth,Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 761) and Erdman (417) correct "greeen" to "green". The misprinted word "greeen" was never corrected by Blake (Bentley *Writings* volume 2, page 761n).
Or the blue regions of the air,
Where the melodious winds have birth;
Whether on chrystal crystal rocks ye rove,
Beneath the bosom of the sea
Wand'ring Wandering in many a coral grove,
Fair Nine, forsaking Poetry!
How have you left the antient ancient love
That bards of old enjoy'd enjoyed in you!
The languid strings do scarcely move!
The sound is forc'dforced, the notes are few!
GWIN, KING OF NORWAY.
COME, Kings, and listen to my song,
When Gwin, the son of Nore,
Over the nations of the North
His cruel sceptrescepter bore:
The Nobles of the land did feed
Upon the hungry Poor;
They tear the poor man's lamb, and drive
The needy from their door!
The land is desolate; our wives
And children cry for bread;
Arise, and pull the tyrant down;
Let Gwin be humbled.
Gordred the giant rous'd roused himself
From sleeping in his cave;
He shook the hills, and in the clouds
The troubl'd troubled banners wave.
Beneath them roll'drolled, like tempests black,
The num'rous numerous sons of blood;
Like lions' whelps, roaring abroad,
Seeking their nightly food.

lg.l: Down Bleron's hills they dreadful rush,
Their cry ascends the clouds;
The trampling horse, and clanging arms

Like rushing mighty floods! Bentley notes that in Copy W, "and clanging arms Like rushing" is deleted and replaced by "[Th]eir hauberks / [*word trimmed off*; ?(flas)h;] the tram / [p]ling horse / Rush on like mighty floods" in a hand unlike Blake's (*Writings* volume 2, page 763n).
Their wives and children, weeping loud,
Follow in wild array,
Howling like ghosts, furious as wolves
In the bleak wintry day.
"Pull down the tyrant to the dust,
"Let Gwin be humbled,"
They cry; "and let ten thousand lives
"Pay for the tyrant's head."
From tow'r tower to tow'r tower the watchmen cry,
"O Gwyn, the son of Nore,
"Arouse thyself! the nations black,
"Like clouds, come rolling o'erover!"
Gwin rear'd reared his shield, his palace shakes,
His chiefs come rushing round;
Each, like an awful thunder cloud,
With voice of solemn sound:Erdman reads "sound." for "sound:" (418).
Like reared stones around a grave
They stand around the King;
Then suddenly each seiz'd seized his spear,
And clashing steel does ring.
KING OF NORWAY. 21
The husbandman does leave his plow,
To wade thro' through fields of gore;
The merchant binds his brows in steel,
And leaves the trading shore:
The shepherd leaves his mellow pipe,
And sounds the trumpet shrill;
The workman throws his hammer down
To heave the bloody bill.
Like the tall ghost of Barraton,
Who sports in stormy sky,
Gwin leads his host as black as night,
When pestilence does fly.
With horses and with chariots—
And all his spearmen bold,
March to the sound of mournful song,
Like clouds around him roll'drolled.
Gwin lifts his hand—the nations halt;
"Prepare for war," he cries——
Gordred appears!—his frowning brow
Troubles our northern skies.
The armies stand, like balances
Held in th' the Almighty's hand;——
"Gwin, thou hast filld filled thy measure up,
"Thou'rtThou art swept from out the land."
22GWIN,
And now the raging armies rush'drushed,
Like warring mighty seas;
The Heav'ns Heavens are shook with roaring war,
The dust ascends the skies!
Earth smokes with blood, and groans, and shakes,
To drink her childrens' gore,
A sea of blood; nor can the eye
See to the trembling shore!
And on the verge of this wild sea
Famine and death doth cry;
The cries of women and of babes
Over the field doth fly.
The King is seen raging afar,
With all his men of might;
Like blazing comets, scattering death
Thro' Through the red fev'rous feverous night.
Beneath his arm like sheep they die,
And groan upon the plain;
The battle faints, and bloody men
Fight upon hills of slain.
Now death is sick, and riven men
Labour and toil for life;
Steed rolls on steed, and shield on shield,
Sunk in this sea of strife!
The god of war is drunk with blood,
The earth doth faint and fail;
The stench of blood makes sick the heav'nsheavens;
Ghosts glut the throat of hell!
O what have Kings to answer for,
Before that awful throne!
When thousand deaths for vengeance cry,
And ghosts accusing groan!
Like blazing comets in the sky,
That shake the stars of light,
Which drop like fruit unto the earth,
Like these did Gwin and Gordred meet,
And the first blow decides;
Down from the brow unto the breast
Gordred his head divides!
Gwin fell; the Sons of Norway fled,
All that remain'd remained alive;
The rest did fill the vale of death,
For them the eagles strive.
The river Dorman roll'd rolled their blood
Into the northern sea;
Who mourn'd mourned his sons, and overwhelm'd overwhelmed
The pleasant south country.

lg.l: AN
IMITATION OF SPENCERSpenser.
GOLDEN Apollo, that thro' through heaven wide
Scatter'st Scatters the rays of light, and truth's beams!
In lucent words my darkling verses dight,

And wash my earthy mind in thy clear streams,Bentley notes that in Copy F "And" is deleted; after the word "wash", "thou" is written in pen and ink by a contemporary hand (*Writings* volume 2, page 766n).
That wisdom may descend in fairy dreams:
All while the jocund hours in thy train
Scatter their fancies at thy poet's feet;
And when thou yields to night thy wide domain,In Copy F, "yields" was corrected to "yield'st" in pen and ink by a contemporary hand (Bentley *Writings* volume 2, page 766n).

Let rays of truth
enlight enlighten his sleeping brain.
For brutish Pan in vain might thee assay
With tinkling sounds to dash thy nervous verse,
Sound without sense; yet in his rude affray,

(For ignorance is Folly's
leesing leasing nurse,

And love of Folly needs none others curse;)Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 767) and Erdman (420) read "other" for "others". Bentley notes that the "s" from "others" is deleted in Copies T and V (*Writings* volume 2, page 767n), while Erdman notes this change for one copy (847).

Midas the praise hath gain'd gained of lengthen'd lengthened cares,Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 767n) reads "ears" instead of "cares" and Erdman (420) reads "eares" for "cares". In Copies Q and T, Bentley notes that "cares" has been emended in pen and ink to "eares"; in Copy F, the correction was made by a contemporary hand in the margin (*Writings* volume 2, page 767n). Erdman notes this change was made in two copies (847).
For which himself might deem him ne'er never the
worse
To sit in council with his modern peers,
And judge of tinkling rhimesrhymes, and elegances terse.
And thou, Mercurius, that with winged brow
Dost mount aloft into the yielding sky,

And thro' through
Heav'n's Heaven's halls thy airy flight dost throw,

lg.l: Entering with holy feet to where on high
Jove weighs the counsel of futurity;
Then, laden with eternal fate, dost go
Down, like a falling star, from autumn sky,
And o'er over the surface of the silent deep dost fly.
If thou arrivest arrive at the sandy shore,
Where nought but envious hissing adders dwell,
Thy golden rod, thrown on the dusty floor,
Can charm to harmony with potent spell;
Such is sweet Eloquence, that does dispel
Envy and Hate, that thirst for human gore:
And cause in sweet society to dwell
Vile savage minds that lurk in lonely cell.
O Mercury, assist my lab'ring laboring sense,
That round the circle of the world wou'd would fly!
As the wing'd winged eagle scorns the tow'ry towery fence
Of Alpine hills round his high aeryaerieeyrie,
And searches thro' through the corners of the sky,
Sports in the clouds to hear the thunder's sound,
And see the winged lightnings as they fly,
Then, bosom'd bosomed in an amber cloud, around
Plumes his wide wings, and seeks Sol's palace high.

And thou, O warrior, maid invincible,Erdman (421) reads "warrior maid, invincible" for "warrior, maid invincible". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 768n) notes "warrior, maid invincible" was changed to "warrior maid, invincible" in Copy Q. Erdman notes this change was made in one copy (847).
Arm'd Armed with the terrors of Almighty Jove!
Pallas, Minerva, maiden terrible,
Lov'st Lovest thou to walk the peaceful solemn grove,
In solemn gloom of branches interwove?
Or bear'st bearest thy Egis o'er over the burning field,
Where, like the sea, the waves of battle move?
Or have thy soft piteous eyes beheld
The weary wanderer thro' through the desert rove?
Or does th' the afflicted man thy heav'nly heavenly bosom move?
WHEN silver Snow decks Susan's cloathsclothes,
And jewel hangs at th' the shepherd's nose,
The blushing bank is all my care,
With hearth so red, and walls so fair;
"Heap the sea-coal; come, heap it higher,
"The oaken log lay on the fire:"
The well-wash'd well-washed stools, a circling row,
With lad and lass, how fair the show!
The merry can of nut-brown ale,
The laughing jest, the love-sicklovesick tale,
'Till tir'd tired of chat, the game begins,
The lasses prick the lads with pins;
Roger from Dolly twitch'd twitched the stool,
She falling, kiss'd kissed the ground, poor fool!
She blush'd blushed so red, with side-long glance
At hob-nail Dick, who griev'd grieved the chance.
But now for Blind-man's Buff they call;
Of each incumbrance clear the hall—
Jenny her silken 'kerchief handkerchief folds,
And blear-ey'd blear-eyed Will the black lot holds;
Now laughing, stops, with "Silence! hush!"
And Peggy Pout gives Sam a push.——
The Blind-man's arms, extended wide,
Sam slips between;—"O woe betide
Thee, clumsy Will!"—but titt'ring tittering Kate
Is pen'd penned up in the corner strait!
And now Will's eyes beheld the play,
He thought his face was t'other the other way.——
"Now, Kitty, now; what chance hast thou,
"Roger so near thee, Trips; I vow!
She catches him—then Roger ties
His own head up—but not his eyes;
For thro' through the slender cloth he sees,
And runs at Sam, who slips with ease
His clumsy hold; and, dodging round,
Sukey is tumbled on the ground!——
"See what it is to play unfair!
"Where cheating is, there's mischief there."
But Roger still pursues the chacechase,—
"He sees! he sees! cries softly Grace;
"O Roger, thou, unskill'd unskilled in art,
"Must, surer bound, go thro' through thy part!"
Now Kitty, pert, repeats the rhymes,
And Roger turns him round three times;
Then pauses ere he starts——but Dick
Was mischief bent upon a trick:
Down on his hands and knees he lay,
Directly in the Blind-man's way—
Then cries out, "Hem!" Hodge heard, and ran
With hood-wink'd hoodwinked chance—sure of his man;

lg.l: But down he came.—Alas, how frail
Our best of hopes, how soon they fail!
With crimson drops he stains the ground,
Confusion startles all around!
Poor piteous Dick supports his head,
And fain would cure the hurt he made;
But Kitty hasted with a key,
And down his back they strait convey
The cold relief—the blood is stay'dstayed,
And Hodge again holds up his head.
Such are the fortunes of the game,
And those who play should stop the same
By wholesome laws; such as all those

Who on the blinded man impose. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 770) and Erdman (423) read "impose," for "impose.". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 770n) and Erdman (847) note that in Copy Q "impose." was changed to "impose,".

Stand in his stead as long a-goneBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 770) and Erdman (423) read "stead;" for "stead". In Copy Q, a semicolon was inserted after "stead" (Bentley *Writings* volume 2, page 770n) (Erdman 847).
When men were first a nation grown;
Lawless they liv'dlived—till wantonness
And one man lay in another's way,
Then laws were made to keep fair play.

lg.l: KING EDWARD THE THIRD.
PERSONS.
Duke of Clarence.William, Dagworth's
Sir John Chandos. Man.
Sir Thomas Dagworth.Peter Blunt, a common
Sir Walter Manny. Soldier.
SCENE,

l.hi: The Coast of France, King Edward and Nobles before

l.note: Both Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 771) and Erdman (423) omit the phrase "before / it". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 771n) and Erdman (847) note that in Copy S, "before / it" has been deleted. Essick (*Huntington* page 178) specifies "before / it" is struck through with horizontal pen and ink lines. Essick also documents the same deletion in Copy Y ("Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 [spring 2012], page 119).

lg.l: O THOU, to whose fury the nations are
But as dust! maintain thy servant's right.
Without thine aid, the twisted mail, and spear,
And forged helm, and shield of seven times beaten
Are idle trophies of the vanquisher. [brass,
When confusion rages, when the field is in a flame,
When the cries of blood tear horror from heav'nheaven,
And yelling death runs up and down the ranks,
Let Liberty, the charter'd chartered right of Englishmen,
Won by our fathers in many a glorious field,
Enerve my soldiers; let Liberty
Blaze in each countenance, and fire the battle.
The enemy fight in chains, invisible chains, but
heavy;
Their minds are fetter'dfettered; then how can they be free,
While, like the mounting flame,
We spring to battle o'er over the floods of death?
And these fair youths, the flow'r flower of England,
Vent'ring Venturing their lives in my most righteous cause,
O sheathe their hearts with triple steel, that they
May emulate their fathers' virtues.
And thou, my son, be strong; thou fightest for a
crown
That death can never ravish from thy brow,
A crown of glory: but from thy very dust
Shall beam a radiance, to fire the breasts
Of youth unborn! Our names are written equal
In fame's wide trophied hall; 'tis ours to gild
The letters, and to make them shine with gold
That never tarnishes: whether Third Edward,
Or the Prince of Wales, or Montacute, or Mor- Mortimer
timerMortimer, [fame,
Or ev'n even the least by birth, shall gain the brightest
Is in his hand to whom all men are equal.
The world of men are like the num'rous numerous stars,
That beam and twinkle in the depth of night,
Each clad in glory according to his sphere;—
But we, that wander from our native seats,
And beam forth lustre luster on a darkling world,
Grow larger as we advance! and some perhaps
The most obscure at home, that scarce were seen
To twinkle in their sphere, may so advance,
That the astonish'd astonished world, with up-turn'd upturned eyes,
Regardless of the moon, and those that once were
Stand only for to gaze upon their splendor! [bright,
[ He here knights the Prince, and other young Nobles.]
Now let us take a just revenge for those
Brave Lords, who fell beneath the bloody axe
At Paris. Thanks, noble Harcourt, for 'twas
By your advice we landed here in Brittany—
A country not yet sown with destruction,
And where the fiery whirlwind of swift war
Has not yet swept its desolating wing.——
Into three parties we divide by day,
And separate march, but join again at night:

Each knows his rank, and Heav'n Heaven
marshal marshall all.
[Exeunt.
SCENE, English Court; Lionel, Duke of Clarence;
MY Lords, I have, by the advice of her
Whom I am doubly bound to obey, my Parent
And my Sovereign, call'd called you together.
My task is great, my burden heavier than
My unfledg'd unfledged years;
Yet, with your kind assistance, Lords, I hope
England shall dwell in peace; that while my father
Toils in his wars, and turns his eyes on this
His native shore, and sees commerce fly round
With his white wings, and sees his golden London,
And her silver Thames, throng'd thronged with shining spires
And corded ships; her merchants buzzing round
Like summer bees, and all the golden cities
In his land, overflowing with honey,
Glory may not be dimm'd dimmed with clouds of care.
Say, Lords, should not our thoughts be first to
commerce?
My Lord Bishop, you would recommend us agri- agriculture
cultureagriculture?
Bishop. Sweet Prince! the arts of peace are great,
And no less glorious than those of war,
Perhaps more glorious in the phlosophic philosophic mind.The word "phlosophic" seems to be a misprint of "philosophic".
When I sit at my home, a private man,
My thoughts are on my gardens, and my fields,
How to employ the hand that lacketh bread.
If Industry is in my diocese,
Religion will flourish; each man's heart
Is cultivated, and will bring forth fruit:
This is my private duty and my pleasure.
But as I sit in council with my prince,
My thoughts take in the gen'ral general good of the whole,
And England is the land favour'd favored by Commerce;
For Commerce, tho' though the child of Agriculture,
Fosters his parent, who else must sweat and toil,
And gain but scanty fare. Then, my dear Lord,
By England's trade our care; and we, as tradesmen,
Looking to the gain of this our native land.

Clar. Clarence
O my good Lord, true wisdom drops like
honey
From your tongue, as from a worship'd worshipped oak!
Forgive, my Lords, my talkative youth, that speaks
Not merely what my narrow observation has
Pick'd Picked up, but what I have concluded from your
lessons:
Now, by the Queen's advice, I ask your leave
To dine to-morrow tomorrow with the Mayor of London:
If I obtain your leave, I have another boon
To ask, which is, the favour favor of your company;
I fear Lord Percy will not give me leave.
Percy. Dear Sir, a prince should always keep his
state,
And grant his favours favors with a sparing hand,
Or they are never rightly valued.
These are my thoughts, yet it were best to go;
But keep a proper dignity, for now
You represent the sacred person of
Your father; 'tis with princes as 'tis with the sun,
If not sometimes o'er-cloudedover-clouded, we grow weary
Of his officious glory.
Clar. Clarence Then you will give me leave to shine some- sometimes
timessometimes,
My Lord?
Lord. Thou hast a gallant spirit, which I fear
Will be imposed on by the closer sort![Aside.
Clar. Clarence Well, I'll endeavour to take
Lord Percy's advice; I have been used so much
To dignity, that I'm sick on'ton it.

Queen Phil. Queen Philippa Fie, Fie, Lord Clarence; you
pro- proceed
ceedproceed not to business,
But speak of your own pleasures.
I hope their Lordships will excuse your giddiness.
Clar. Clarence My Lords, the French have fitted out many
Small ships of war, that, like to ravening wolves,
Infest our English seas, devouring all
Our burden'd burdened vessels, spoiling our naval flocks.
The merchants do complain, and beg our aid.
Percy. The merchants are rich enough;
Can they not help themselves?[will,
Bish. Bishop They can, and may; but how to gain their
Requires our countenance and help.
Percy. When that they find they must, my Lord,
they will:
Let them but suffer awhile, and you shall see
They will bestir themselves.
Bish. Bishop Lord Percy cannot mean that we should
suffer
This disgrace; if so, we are not sovereigns
Of the sea; our right, that Heaven gave
To England, when at the birth of nature
She was seated in the deep, the Ocean ceas'd ceased
His mighty roar; and, fawning, play'd played around
Her snowy feet, and own'd owned his awful Queen.
Lord Percy, if the heart is sick, the head
Must be aggriev'daggrieved; if but one member suffer,
The heart doth fail. You say, my Lord, the
merchants
Can, if they will, defend themselves against
These rovers: this is a noble scheme,
Worthy the brave Lord Percy, and as worthy
His generous aid to put it into practice.
Percy. Lord Bishop, what was rash in me, is wise
In you; I dare not own the plan. 'Tis not
Mine. Yet will I, if you please,

Quickly to the Lord Mayor, and work him
on- onward
To this most glorious voyage, on which cast
I'll set my whole estate.
But we will bring these Gallic rovers under.
Queen Phil. Queen Philippa Thanks, brave Lord Percy; you
have the thanks
Of England's Queen, and will, ere long, of Eng- England
land.[Exeunt.
SCENE, At CresseyCressy. Sir Thomas Dagworth and
Aud. Audley Good morrow, brave Sir Thomas; the
bright morn
Smiles on our army, and the gallant sun
Springs from the hills like a young hero
Into the battle, shaking his golden locks
Exultingly; this is a promising day.
Dagw. Dagworth Why, my Lord Audley, I don't know.
Give me your hand, and now I'll tell you what
I think you do not know—Edward's afraid of
Philip.
Did you eree're see him fear? At Blanchetaque,
When almost singly he drove six thousand
French from the ford, did he fear then?
Dagw. Dagworth Yes, fear; that made him fight so.
Aud. Audley By the same reason I might say, 'tis fear
That makes you fight.
Dagw. Dagworth Mayhap you may; look upon Edward's
face—
No one can say he fears. But when he turns
His back, then I will say it to his face,
He is afraid; he makes us all afraid.
I cannot bear the enemy at my back.
Now here we are at Cressy; where, to-morrowtomorrow,
To-morrow Tomorrow we shall know. I say, Lord Audley,
That Edward runs away from Philip.
Aud. Audley Perhaps you think the Prince too is
afraid?
Dagw. Dagworth No; God forbid! I'm sure he is not—
He is a young lion. O I have seen him fight,
And give command, and lightning has flashed
From his eyes across the field; I have seen him
Shake hands with death, and strike a bargain for
The enemy; he has danc'd danced in the field
Of battle, like the youth at morrice play.
I'm sure he's not afraid, nor Warwick, nor none,
None of us but me; and I am very much afraid.
Aud. Audley Are you afraid too, Sir Thomas?
I believe that as much as I believe
The King's afraid; but what are you afraid of?

Dagw. Dagworth
Of having my back laid open; we turn
Our backs to the fire, till we shall burn our skirts.
Aud. Audley And this, Sir Thomas, you call fear? Your
fear
Is of a different kind then from the King's;
He fears to turn his face, and you to turn your
back.—
I do not think, Sir Thomas, you know what fear is.
Chand. Chandos Good morrow, Generals; I give you joy:
Welcome to the fields of Cressy. Here we stop,
And wait for Philip.
Dagw. Dagworth I hope so.
Aud. Audley There, Sir Thomas; do you call that fear?
Dagw. Dagworth I don't know; perhaps he takes it by
fits.
Why, noble Chandos, look you here—
One rotten sheep spoils the whole flock;
And if the bell-weather is tainted, I wish
The Prince may not catch the distemper too.
Chand. Chandos Distemper, Sir Thomas! what distem- distemper
perdistemper?
I have not heard.
Dagw. Dagworth Why, Chandos, you are a wise man,
I know you understand me; a distemper
The King caught here in France of running away.
Aud. Audley Sir Thomas, you say, you have caught it
too.
Dag. Dagworth And so will the whole army; 'tis very
catching,
For when the coward runs, the brave man totters.
Perhaps the air of the country is the cause.—
I feel it coming upon me, so I strive against it;
You yet are whole, but after a few more
Retreats, we all shall know how to retreat
Better than fight.—To be plain, I think retreating
Too often, takes away a soldier's courage.
Chand. Chandos Here comes the King himself; tell him
your thoughts
Plainly, Sir Thomas.
Dagw. Dagworth I've told him before, but his disorder
Makes him deaf.

l.hi: Enter King Edward and Black Prince.

lg.l: King. Good morrow, Generals; when English
courage fails,
Down goes our right to France;
Can stand our soldiers; each man is worthy
Of a triumph. Such an army of heroes
Ne'erNever shouted to the Heav'nsHeavens, nor shook the field.
Edward, my son, thou art
Most happy, having such command; the man
Were base who were not fir'd fired to deeds
Above heroic, having such examples.
Prince. Sire! with respect and deference I look
Upon such noble souls, and with myself
Worthy the high command that Heaven and you
Have given me. When I have seen the field glow,
And in each countenance the soul of war
Curb'd Curbed by the manliest reason, I have been wing'd winged
With certain victory; and 'tis my boast,
And shall be still my glory. I was inspir'd inspired
By these brave troops.
Dagw. Dagworth Your Grace had better make
Them all Generals.
King. Sir Thomas Dagworth, you must have
your joke,
And shall, while you can fight as you did at
The Ford.
Dagw. Dagworth I have a small petition to your Majesty.
King. What can Sir Thomas Dagworth ask,
that Edward
Can refuse?
Dagw. Dagworth I hope your Majesty cannot refuse so
great
A trifle; I've gilt your cause with my best blood,
And would again, were I not forbid
By him whom I am bound to obey: my hands
Are tied up, my courage shrunk and wither'dwithered,
My sinews slacken'dslackened, and my voice scarce heard;
Therefore I beg I may return to England.
King. I know not what you could have ask'dasked,
Sir Thomas,
That I would not have sooner parted with
Than such a soldier as you have been, and such a
friend;
Nay, I will know the most remote particulars
Of this your strange petition; that, if I can,
I still may keep you here.
Dagw. Dagworth Here on the fields of Cressy we are set- settled
tledsettled,
'Till Philip springs the tim'rous timorous covey again.
The Wolf is hunted down by causeless fear;
The Lion flees, and fear usurps his heart;
Startled, astonish'd astonished at the clam'rous clamorous Cock;
The Eagle, that doth gaze upon the sun,
Fears the small fire that plays about the fen;
If, at this moment of their idle fear,
The Dog doth seize the Wolf, the Forester the
Lion,
The Negro in the crevice of the rock,
Doth seize the soaring Eagle; undone by flight,
They tame submit: such the effect flight has
On noble souls. Now hear its opposite:
The tim'rous timorous Stag starts from the thicket wild,
The fearful Crane springs from the splashy fen,
The shining Snake glides o'er over the bending grass,
The Stag turns head! and bays the crying Hounds;
The Crane o'ertakenovertaken, fighteth fights with the Hawk; Probably misreading an f for a long s, Erdman reads "sighteth" for "fighteth" (430).
The Snake doth turn, and bite the padding foot;
And, if your Majesty's afraid of Philip,
You are more like a Lion than a Crane:
Therefore I beg I may return to England.
King. Sir Thomas, now I understand your mirth,
Which often plays with Wisdom for its pastime,
And brings good counsel from the breast of laugh- laughter
terlaughter,
I hope you'll stay, and see us fight this battle,
And reap rich harvest in the fields of Cressy;
Then go to England, tell them how we fight,
And set all hearts on fire to be with us.
Philip is plum'dplumed, and thinks we flee from him,
Else he would never dare to attack us. Now,
Now the quarry's set! and Death doth sport
In the bright sunshine of this fatal day.
Dagw. Dagworth Now my heart dances, and I am as light
As the young bridegroom going to be married.
Now must I to my soldiers, get them ready,
Furbish our armours bright, new plume our helms,
And we will sing, like the young housewives busied
In the dairy; my feet are wing'dwinged, but not
For flight, an please your grace.
King. If all my soldiers are as pleas'd pleased as you,
'Twill be a gallant thing to fight or die;
Then I can never be afraid of Philip.
Dagw. Dagworth A raw-bon'd raw-boned fellow t'other the other day pass'd passed by
me;
I told him to put off his hungry looks—
He answer'd answered me, "I hunger for another battle."
I saw a little WelchmanWelshman with a fiery face;
I told him he look'd looked like a candle half
Burn'd Burned out; he answer'danswered, he was "pig enough
"To light another pattle." Last night, beneath
The moon I walk'd walked abroad, when all had pitch'd pitched
Their tents, and all were still,
I heard a blooming youth singing a song
He had compos'dcomposed, and at each pause he wip'd wiped
His dropping eyes. The ditty was, "if he
"Return'dReturned victorious, he should wed a maiden
"Fairer than snow, and rich as midsummer."
Another wept, and wish'd wished health to his father.
I chidchided them both, but gave them noble hopes.
These are the minds that glory in the battle,
And leap and dance to hear the trumpet sound.
King. Sir Thomas Dagworth, be thou near our
person;
Thy heart is richer than the vales of France:
I will not part with such a man as thee.
If Philip came arm'd armed in the ribs of death,
And shook his mortal dart against my head,
Thoud'st Thou wouldst laugh his fury into nerveless shame!
Go now, for thou art suited to the work,
Throughout the camp; enflame the timorous,
Blow up the sluggish into ardourardor, and
Confirm the strong with strength, the weak inspire,
And wing their brows with hope and expectation:
Then to our tent return, and meet to council.
[ Exit Dagworth.
Chand. Chandos That man's a hero in his closet, and
more
A hero to the servants of his house
Than to the gaping world; he carries windowsErdman misreads "Then" for "Than" (431).
In that enlarged breast of his, that all
May see what's done within.

Prince. He is a genuine Englishman, my
Chan- Chandos
dosChandos,
And hath the spirit of Liberty within him.
Forgive my prejudice, Sir John; I think
My Englishmen the bravest people on
The face of the earth.
Chand. Chandos Courage, my Lord, proceeds from self- self-dependence
dependenceself-dependence;
Teach man to think he's a free agent,
Give but a slave his liberty, he'll shake
Off sloth, and build himself a hut, and hedge
A spot of ground; this he'll defend; 'tis his
By right of nature: thus set in action,
He will still move onward to plan conveniences,
'Till glory fires his breast to enlarge his castle,
While the poor slave drudges all day, in hope
To rest at night.
King. O Liberty, how glorious art thou!

I see thee hov'ring hovering
o'er over my army, with
Thy wide-stretch'dstretched plumes; I see thee
Lead them on to battle;
I see thee blow thy golden trumpet, while
Thy sons shout the strong shout of victory!A crease in the page runs through "victory!"
O noble Chandos! think thyself a gardener,The same crease also runs through the top of the first four words of line 22.
My son a vine, which I commit unto
Thy care; prune all extravagant shoots, and guide
Water him with thy advice, and Heav'n Heaven
Rain fresh'ning freshening dew upon his branches. And,
O Edward, my dear son! learn to think lowly of
Thyself, as we may all each prefer other—
'Tis the best policy, and 'tis our duty.
[ Exeunt King Edward.

objnote.p:
While most of the emendations across the corrected copies are assumed to have been made by Blake, the authorship of some emendations is disputed. Unless otherwise noted, our default attribution is to Blake. For further information on the emendations in *Poetical Sketches* and their attributions, see:
Bentley pages 343-54
Bentley, *Writings* vol 2, pages 749-99
[Essick, Robert. "Blake in the Marketplace, 2011," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 45.4 (spring 2012)](http://bq.blakearchive.org/45.4.essick#PS)
Essick, *Huntington* pages 176-78
Erdman pages 408-45, 846-48
[Phillips, Michael. "Blake’s Corrections in *Poetical Sketches*," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 4.2 (fall 1970)](http://bq.blakearchive.org/4.2.phillips).

lg.l: Prince. And may our duty, Chandos, be our
pleasure—
Now we are alone, Sir John, I will unburden,
And breathe my hopes into the burning air,
Where thousand deaths are posting up and down,
Methinks I see them arm my gallant soldiers,
And gird the sword upon each thigh, and fit
Each shining helm, and string each stubborn
bow,
And dance to the neighing of our steeds.
Methinks the shout begins, the battle burns;
Methinks I see them perch on English crests,
And roar the wild flame of fierce war, upon
The thronged enemy! In truth, I am too full;
It is my sin to love the noise of war.
Chandos, thou seestsee my weakness; strong nature
Will bend or break us; my blood, like a spring- springtide
tidespringtide,
Does rise so high, to overflow all bounds

Of moderation; while Reason, in herA crease runs across the page and through "while" and the first three characters of "Reason".Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 782) and Erdman (432) read "his" for "her". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 782n) notes that "her" has been altered to "his" in Copies T and V, while Erdman notes that this change occurs in one copy (847).
Frail bark, can see no shore or bound for vast
Ambition. Come, take the helm, my Chandos,
That my full-blown sails overset me not
In the wild tempest; condemn my 'ventrous venturous adventurous
youth,
That plays with danger, as the innocent child,
Unthinking, plays upon the viper's den:
I am a coward, in my reason, Chandos.
Chand. Chandos You are a man, my prince, and a brave
man,
If I can judge of actions; but your heat
Is the effect of youth, and want of use;
Use makes the armed field and noisy war
Pass over as a summer cloud, unregarded,
Or but expected as a thing of course.
Age is contemplative; each rolling year
Brings forth fruit to the mind's treasure-house;
While vacant youth doth crave and seek about
Within itself, and findeth finds discontent:
Then, tir'd tired of thought, impatient takes the wing,
Seizes the fruits of time, attacks experience,
Roams round vast Nature's forest, where no bounds
Are set, the swiftest may have room, the strongest
Find prey; till tir'd tired at length, sated and tired
With the changing sameness, old variety,
We sit us down, and view our former joys
With distaste and dislike.
Prince. Then if we must tug for experience,
Let us not fear to beat round Nature's wilds,
And rouze rouse the strongest prey; then if we fall,
We fall with glory; I know the wolf
Is dangerous to fight, not good for food,
Nor is the hide a comely vestment; so
We have our battle for our pains. I know
That youth has need of age to point fit prey,
And oft the stander-by bystander shall steal the fruit
Of th' the other's labourlabor. This is philosophy;
These are the tricks of the world; but the pure soul

lg.l: Shall mount on native wings, disdaining
Little sport, and cut a path into the heaven of
glory,
Leaving a track of light for men to wonder at.
I'm glad my father does not hear me talk;
You can find friendly excuses for me, Chandos;
But do you not think, Sir John, that if it please
Th' The Almighty to stretch out my span of life,
I shall with pleasure view a glorious action,
Which my youth master'dmastered.
Chand. Chandos Considerate age, my Lord, views motives,
And not acts; when neither warbling voice,
Nor trilling pipe is heard, nor pleasure sits
With trembling age; the voice of Conscience then,
Sweeter than music in a summer's eve,
Shall warble round the snowy head, and keep
Sweet symphony to feather'd feathered angels, sitting
As guardians round your chair; then shall the
pulse
Beat slow, and taste, and touch, and sight, and
sound, and smell,
That sing and dance round Reason's fine-wrought
throne,

Shall flee away, and leave them all forlorn;Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 782) and Erdman (433) read "him" for "them". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 783n) notes that "them" has been altered to "him" in Copies T and V, while Erdman notes that the change occurs in one copy (847).
Yet not forlorn if Conscience is his friend.
[ Exeunt.

SCENE in Sir Thomas Dagworth's Tent.
Dag- Dagworth
Dagw. Dagworth Bring hither my armourarmor, William;
Ambition is the growth of ev'ry every clime.
Will. William Does it grow in England, Sir?
Dagw. Dagworth Aye, it grows most in lands most culti- cultivated
vatedcultivated.
Will. William Then it grows most in France; the vines
here
Are finer than any we have in England.
Dagw. Dagworth Aye, but the oaks are not.
Will. William What is the tree you mentioned? I don't
think
I ever saw it.
Dagw. Dagworth Ambition.
Will. William Is it a little creeping root that grows in
ditches?
Dagw. Dagworth Thou dost not understand me, William.
It is a root that grows in every breast;
Ambition is the desire or passion that one man
Has to get before another, in any pursuit after glory;
But I don't think you have any of it.
Will. William Yes, I have; I have a great ambition to
know every thing, Sir.
Dagw. Dagworth But when our first ideas are wrong, what
follows must all be wrong of course; 'tis best to
know a little, and to know that little aright.
Will. William Then, Sir, I should be glad to know if it
was not ambition that brought over our King to
France to fight for his right?

Dagw. Dagworth
Tho' Though the knowledge of that will not pro- profit

fitprofit thee much, yet I will tell you that it was
ambi- ambition
tionambition.
Will. William Then if ambition is a sin, we are all guilty
in coming with him, and in fighting for him.
Dagw. Dagworth Now, William, thou dost thrust the
question home; but I must tell you, that guilt
being an act of the mind, none are guilty but those
whose minds are prompted by that same ambition.
Will. William Now I always thought, that a man might
be guilty of doing wrong, without knowing it was
wrong.
Dagw. Dagworth Thou art a natural philosopher, and
knowest know truth by instinct; while reason runs a- aground

groundaground, as we have run our argument. Only
re- remember
memberremember, William, all have it in their power to
know the motives of their own actions, and 'tis a
sin to act without some reason.
Will. William And whoever acts without reason, may do
a great deal of harm without knowing it.
Dagw. Dagworth Thou art an endless moralist.
Will. William Now there's a story come into my head,
That I will tell your honourhonor, if you'll give me
leave.

this is no time for
story-tellingstorytelling; but here comes
one who is as entertaining as a good story.
Peter. Yonder's a musician going to play before
the King; it's a new song about the French and
English, and the Prince has made the minstrel a
'squiresquireesquire, and given him I don't know what, and I
can't tell whether he don't mention us all one by
one; and he is to write another about all us that
are to die, that we may be remembered in Old
England, for all our blood and bones are in France;
and a great deal more that we shall all hear by and
by; and I came to tell your honourhonor, because you
love to hear war-songs.
Dagw. Dagworth And who is this minstrel, Peter, do'st do you
know?
Peter. O aye, I forgot to tell that; he has got
the same name as Sir John Chandos, that the
prince is always with—the wise man, that knows
us all as well as your honourhonor, only e'nt isn't so good
natur'dnatured.
Dagw. Dagworth I thank you, Peter, for your informa- information
tioninformation, but not for your compliment, which is not
true; there's as much difference between him and
me, as between glittering sand and fruitful mold;
or shining glass and a wrought diamond, set in
rich gold, and fitted to the finger of an emperor:
such is that worthy Chandos.Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 785) misreads "Dhandos" for "Chandos".
Peter. I know your honour honor does not think any
thing of yourself, but every body else does.
Dagw. Dagworth Go, Peter, get you gone; flattery is de- delicious
liciousdelicious, even from the lips of a babbler. [ Exit Peter.
Will. William I never flatter your honourhonor.
Dagw. Dagworth I don't know that.
Will. William Why you know, Sir, when we were in
England, at the tournament at Windsor, and the
Earl of Warwick was tumbled over, you ask'd asked me
if he did not look well when he fell? and I said,
No, he look'd looked very foolish; and you was very an- angry
gryangry with me for not flattering you.
Dagw. Dagworth You mean that I was angry with you for
not flattering the Earl of Warwick.
[ Exeunt.
SCENE, Sir Thomas Dagworth's Tent. Sir Tho- Thomas
Sir Walter. Sir Thomas Dagworth, I have been
weeping
Over the men that are to die to-daytoday.
Dagw. Dagworth Why, brave Sir Walter, you or I may
fall.
Sir Walter. I know this breathing flesh must lie
and rot,
Cover'd Covered with silence and forgetfulness.—
Death wons in cities' smoke, and in still night,
When men sleep in their beds, walketh about!
How many in walled cities lie and groan,
Turning themselves upon their beds,
Talking with death, answering his hard demands!
How many walk in darkness, terrors are round
The curtains of their beds, destruction is
Ready at the door! How many sleep
In earth, cover'd covered with stones and deathy dust,
Resting in quietness, whose spirits walk
Upon the clouds of heaven, to die no more!
Yet death is terrible, tho' though borne on angels' wings!
How terrible then is the field of death,
Where he doth rend the vault of heaven,
And shake the gates of hell!
O Dagworth, France is sick! the very sky,
Tho' Though sunshine light it, seems to me as pale

As the pale fainting man on his
death-beddeathbed,
Whose face is shewn shown by light of sickly taper!
It makes me sad and sick at very heart,

Thousands must fall
to-daytoday!
Dagw. Dagworth Thousands of souls must leave this pri- prison-house
son-houseprison-house,
To be exalted to those heavenly fields,
Where songs of triumph, palms of victory,
Where peace, and joy, and love, and calm con- content
tentcontent,
Sit singing in the azure clouds, and strew
Flowers of heaven's growth over the banquet-table:
Bind ardent Hope upon your feet like shoes,
Put on the robe of preparation,
The table is prepar'd prepared in shining heaven,
The flowers of immortality are blown;

Let those that fight, fight in good
stedfastnesssteadfastness,
And those that fall shall rise in victory.
